title: The gold scandal that ended a Labor career
text:
The deals showed remarkable trust between Mr Zhou and Mr Wang, with little or no documentation, and little or no attempts to verify the purity of the gold being traded in deals worth millions of dollars.

Mr Zhou must have taken Mr Wang at his word as to the purity of what he was buying.

In a quirk of the tax law, GST is payable on scrap metal, but not on bullion.

This meant while Mr Wang’s headline profit on the gold trades was only $600,000, he was able to claim $14.3 million in GST refunds – a position gold traders say is a loophole. The ATO disagrees.

In November 2016, the ATO sought $2.7 million in over-claimed GST from Mr Zhou’s Australian Coin Exchange. Meanwhile, two gold companies associated with Mr Wang received $76 million in tax bills.

Mr Zhou appointed a liquidator to Australian Coin Exchange in May 2017.

When the gold-trading scandal was made public in June 2017 by The Sydney Morning Herald and The Age, together with his links to China’s Communist Party, Mr Zhou was forced to resign his Labor Party job.

Unfazed, just two months later he was campaigning hard to win a seat on Ryde Council as an independent.

Advertisement

Less than a month later, Mr Zhou was elected to the council and told reporters the gold matter was now closed and he had “nothing to explain and nothing to hide”.

“I was never sued and never charged,” he said.

He told The Australian: “First of all I want to say this is nothing like a fraud, it is nothing like that, and the taxation office never said that the businesses ever had any fraud activity.”

Mr Zhou said tax difficulties arose because of an “unfortunate business mistake”.

Last December – after the ATO forced a change in liquidator for Mr Zhou’s company Australian Coin Exchange – Vaughan Strawbridge of Deloitte said he was investigating possible recovery actions for “unfair preference payments, insolvent trading, uncommercial transactions and … unreasonable director-related transactions”.
description: In July 2017, Simon Zhou resigned from Labor's NSW headquarters. Two months later he was running for Ryde Council as an independent.
